text:
A dog’s purpose is not to be an actor: Your Say Readers react to allegations of animal abuse on the set of "A Dog’s Purpose." Post to Facebook A dog’s purpose is not to be an actor: Your Say Readers react to allegations of animal abuse on the set of "A Dog’s Purpose."  //usat.ly/2kux2Hf   Join the Nation's Conversation   A dog’s purpose is not to be an actor: Your Say USA TODAY 6:51 p.m. ET Jan. 25, 2017 Readers react to allegations of animal abuse on the set of "A Dog’s Purpose." Image released by Universal Studios shows a scene from "A Dog's Purpose." (Photo: AP) 
Letter to the editor: 
No amount of spin can change the fact that an animal was terrorized during the filming of a scene for A Dog’s Purpose — especially since computer-generated imagery could easily have been used instead. 
The dog, Hercules, made his feelings known loud and clear about being forced into rushing water and struggled desperately to escape — yet he was forced into the pool anyway. Perhaps it’s easy to dismiss being submerged when you’re not the one desperate for air, but for him, it was undeniably terrifying. And it’s not just the on-set cruelty: PETA’s recent exposé of Birds & Animals Unlimited — the reported animal supplier for the movie — revealed that animals were denied veterinary care, forced to sleep outdoors in the cold without bedding, kept in filthy conditions and deprived of food as a training technique. 
There is no humane way to force animals to perform for film and TV. Caring people will avoid such productions. 
Lisa Lange, PETA; Norfolk, Va. Policing the USA 
Facebook comments are edited for clarity and grammar: 
I absolutely believe in the humane treatment of animals, and from what I can gather, this movie production has been predominantly compliant. 
However, any time I ever see a People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals protest, I’m suspicious. The group’s agenda is super extremist and punitive, rather than informative and helpful. Its members pretty much act like self-righteous thugs, and any question to their credibility has come by their own hands. I appreciate their message, but not their delivery. 
— Michael Anthony Shea 
If you wouldn’t film a movie that would do the same “stunt” with a child because it would be considered too dangerous and abusive, then you can safely say you wouldn’t do it to a vulnerable animal either. 
No way anyone could enjoy a movie like this knowing it completely ignored the terror inflicted on Hercules. Unbelievable the cold, callous money-grubbing people who participated in this movie. 
— Joe Bloe  //usat.ly/2kux2Hf
